{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2012}} The '''2010–2014 Portuguese financial crisis''' was part of the wider downturn of the [[economy of Portugal|Portuguese economy]] that started in 2001 and possibly ended in 2016–17.<ref name="FT 2018">{{cite web |url=https://www.ft.com/content/cd5642e2-1175-11e8-8cb6-b9ccc4c4dbbb |title=Portugal grows at fastest rate since 2000 |last=Wise |first=Peter |date=14 February 2018 |website= |publisher=Financial Times |access-date=30 July 2018 |quote=}}</ref> The period from 2010 to 2014 was probably the hardest and more challenging part of the entire economic crisis; this period includes the [[Economic Adjustment Programme for Portugal|2011–14 international bailout to Portugal]] and was marked by an intense austerity policy, intenser than in any other period of the wider 2001–17 crisis. Economic growth stalled in Portugal in 2001–02; following years of internal economic crisis, the (international) [[Great Recession]] started to hit [[Portugal]]<ref>{{cite journal|url=|doi=10.1016/j.healthpol.2014.12.015|pmid=25583679|title=The Great Recession in Portugal: Impact on hospital care use|journal=Health Policy|volume=119|issue=3|pages=307–315|date=24 December 2014|last1=Perelman|first1=Julian|last2=Felix|first2=Sónia|last3=Santana|first3=Rui}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/259753958|title=The elections of the Great Recession in Portugal: performance voting under a blurred responsibility for the economy}}</ref> in 2008 and eventually led to the country being unable to repay or refinance its government debt without the assistance of third parties. To prevent an insolvency situation in the [[debt crisis]], Portugal applied in April 2011 for bail-out programs and drew a cumulated €78.0 billion from the [[International Monetary Fund|International Monetary Fund (IMF)]], the [[European Financial Stabilisation Mechanism|European Financial Stabilisation Mechanism (EFSM)]], and the [[European Financial Stability Facility|European Financial Stability Facility (EFSF)]]. Portugal exited the bailout in May 2014,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-eurozone-portugal-bailout/portugal-exits-bailout-poorer-and-long-way-from-recovery-idUSBREA4F08020140516 |title=Portugal exits bailout poorer and long way from recovery |last1=Bugge |first1=Alex |last2=Khalip |first2=Andrei |date=16 May 2014 |newspaper=Reuters |access-date=30 July 2018 |quote=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/05/06/business/international/bailout-is-over-for-portugal-but-side-effects-will-linger.html |title=Bailout Is Over for Portugal, but Side Effects Will Linger |last=Minder |first=Raphael |date=5 May 2014 |newspaper=The New York Times |access-date=30 July 2018 |quote=}}</ref> the same year that positive economic growth re-appeared following three years of recession.<ref name="Pordata growth rate" /> The government achieved a 2.1% budget deficit in 2016 (the lowest since the [[Carnation Revolution|restoration of democracy]] in 1974)<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.ft.com/content/cd87cce9-499c-35a9-901c-04e19b7d8a3d |title=Portugal's budget deficit falls to 40-year low at 2.1% |last=Wise |first=Peter |date=24 March 2017 |website= |publisher=Financial Times |access-date=30 July 2018 |quote=}}</ref> and in 2017 the economy grew 2.7% (the highest growth rate since 2000).<ref>{{cite web |url=https://econews.pt/2018/02/14/portuguese-economy-grows-2-7-in-2017-the-largest-growth-since-2000/ |title=Portuguese economy grows 2.7% in 2017, the largest growth since 2000 |date=14 February 2018 |website= |publisher=ECO |access-date=13 August 2018 |quote=}}</ref>
==Causes== [[File:Manuela Ferreira Leite.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.2|[[Manuela Ferreira Leite]] was Minister of Finance from 2002 to 2004, in the cabinet of [[José Manuel Durão Barroso]].]] [[File:Josesocrates2006.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.2|From 2005 to 2011, [[José Sócrates]] of the [[Socialist Party (Portugal)|Socialist Party]] (PS) was the prime minister and the leader of the Portuguese Government.]] [[File:Portugal Prime Minister Pedro Passos Coelho with Zapatero.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.2|Prime Ministers [[Pedro Passos Coelho]], from Portugal (left), and [[Rodriguez Zapatero]], from Spain, in October 2011. With economic downturn and a rising unemployment rate (over 10% unemployment rate in Portugal and 20% in Spain by 2011), the two countries of the [[Iberian Peninsula]] were trapped right in the middle of the [[European sovereign debt crisis]].]]
===2000s economic crisis=== Unlike other European countries that were also severely hit by the Great Recession in the late 2000s and received bailouts in the early 2010s (such as [[Greek government-debt crisis|Greece]] and [[Post-2008 Irish economic downturn|Ireland]]), in Portugal the 2000s were not marked by economic growth, but instead were already a period of economic crisis, marked by stagnation, two recessions (in 2002–03<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.publico.pt/2003/03/13/economia/noticia/portugal-entrou-em-recessao-no-quarto-trimestre-de-2002-284735 |title=Portugal entrou em recessão no quarto trimestre de 2002 |last=Melo |first=Eduardo |date=13 March 2003 |website= |publisher=Público |language=Portuguese |trans-title=Portugal entered recession in the fourth quarter of 2002 |access-date=5 July 2018 |quote=}}</ref><ref name="GDP growth" /> and 2008–09<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.rtp.pt/noticias/economia/portugal-fechou-2008-em-recessao_v183214 |title=Portugal fechou 2008 em recessão |last= |first= |date=13 February 2009 |website= |publisher=RTP |language=Portuguese |trans-title=Portugal ended 2008 in recession |access-date=5 July 2018 |quote=}}</ref><ref name="GDP growth" />) and government-sponsored fiscal austerity in order to reduce the budget deficit to the limits allowed by the European Union's [[Stability and Growth Pact]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.publico.pt/2002/06/28/jornal/medidas-de-austeridade-poderao-evitar-multas-por-defice-excessivo-172124 |title=Medidas de austeridade poderão evitar multas por défice excessivo |last=Arriaga e Cunha |first=Isabel |date=28 June 2002 |website= |publisher=Público |language=Portuguese |trans-title=Austerity measures may avoid fines due to excessive deficit |access-date=28 June 2018 |quote=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |date=25 March 2004 |title=Stability pays |url=http://www.economist.com/node/2545844 |newspaper=The Economist |access-date=5 July 2018 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Cambon |first=Diane |date=27 June 2008 |title=Budget, impôts, retraite : la leçon d'austérité du Portugal |trans-title=Bugdet, taxes, reforms: Portugal's lesson of austerity |url=http://www.lefigaro.fr/economie/2008/06/27/04001-20080627ARTFIG00357-budget-impots-retraite-la-lecon-d-austerite-du-portugal.php |language=French |newspaper=Le Figaro |access-date=5 July 2018 }}</ref>
From the early 1960s to the early 2000s, Portugal endured three periods of robust economic growth and socio-economic development (approximately from 1960 to 1973, from 1985 to 1992 and from 1995 to 2001)<ref name="Pordata growth rate">{{cite web |url=https://www.pordata.pt/Portugal/Taxa+de+crescimento+real+do+PIB-2298 |title=Taxa de crescimento real do PIB |date= |website= |publisher=Pordata |language=Portuguese |trans-title=GDP real growth rate |access-date=4 July 2018 |quote=}}</ref> which made the country's [[GDP per capita]] to rise from 39% of the Northern-Central European average in 1960<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.rug.nl/ggdc/historicaldevelopment/maddison/data/mpd_2013-01.xlsx |title=Maddison Project Database, version 2013 |last1=Bolt |first1=J. |last2= van Zanden |first2=J.L.|date=2014 |website=Maddison Project Database |access-date=3 July 2018 |quote=In 1960 (cell A182), Portugal had a GDP per capita of $2,956 (in 1990 US dollars) (cell Q182) while EU-12 countries had a GDP per capita of $7,498 (in 1990 US dollars) (cell N182). Thus, Portuguese GDP per capita was 39,4% of EU-12 average.}}</ref> to 70% in 2000.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.rug.nl/ggdc/historicaldevelopment/maddison/data/mpd_2013-01.xlsx |title=Maddison Project Database, version 2013 |last1=Bolt |first1=J. |last2= van Zanden |first2=J.L.|date=2014 |website=Maddison Project Database |access-date=3 July 2018 |quote=In 2000 (cell A222), Portugal had a GDP per capita of $13,922 (in 1990 US dollars) (cell Q222) while EU-12 countries had a GDP per capita of $20,131 (in 1990 US dollars) (cell N222). Thus, Portuguese GDP per capita was 69,2% of EU-12 average.}}</ref> Although, by 2000, Portugal was still the poorest country in Western Europe, it nevertheless had achieved a level of convergence with the developed economies in Central and Northern Europe which had no precedents in the previous centuries, a catching-up process which was expected to continue.<ref name="The Atlantic 2013">{{cite web |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2013/06/the-mystery-of-why-portugal-is-so-doomed/276371/ |title=The Mystery of Why Portugal Is So Doomed |last=O'Brien |first=Mathew |date=5 June 2013 |website= |publisher=The Atlantic |access-date=28 June 2018 |quote=}}</ref> Portugal still entered well in the 2000s, registering an almost 4% GDP growth rate in 2000,<ref name="GDP growth" /> but growth slowed along 2001; that year's growth rate was 2.0%<ref name="GDP growth" /> and the unexpected slowdown was one of the causes that made the government's (still led by [[António Guterres]]) budget deficit to slip to 4.1%;<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.jornaldenegocios.pt/economia/detalhe/defice_orcamental_nacional_atingiu_os_41_do_pib_em_2001_act |title=Défice orçamental nacional atingiu os 4,1% do PIB em 2001 |last=Domingos |first=Ricardo |date=25 July 2002 |website= |publisher=Jornal de Negócios |language=Portuguese |trans-title=National budget deficit was 4.1% of the GDP in 2001 |access-date=28 June 2018 |quote=}}</ref><ref name="2005 EC Report">{{cite report |author= |author-link= |authors= |date=22 July 2005 |title=Technical document by the Commission Services accompanying the Report on Portugal prepared in accordance with Article 104(3) of the Treaty |url=http://ec.europa.eu/economy_finance/economic_governance/sgp/pdf/30_edps/104-03/2005-06-22_pt_104-3_working_document_en.pdf |publisher=Commission of the European Communities |page= |docket= |access-date=28 June 2018 |quote= }}</ref> Portugal thus became the first [[Eurozone]] country to clearly break the [[Stability and Growth Pact|SGP]]'s 3% limit for the budget deficit, and thus, it was opened an excessive deficit procedure. The [[2002 Portuguese legislative election|2002 snap election]] brought to power the [[Social Democrats]] led by [[José Manuel Durão Barroso]]; his government was marked by the introduction of harsh fiscal austerity policies and structural reforms, mainly justified by the need to reduce the budget deficit, a set of policies designed by his Finance Minister [[Manuela Ferreira Leite]].{{sfn|Commission of the European Communities|2005|p=8}} Portuguese economy grew a combined 0.8% in 2002, was in recession in 2003 (-0.9%) and grew 1.6% in 2004.<ref name="GDP growth">{{cite web |url=https://www.ine.pt/ngt_server/attachfileu.jsp?look_parentBoui=96968544&att_display=n&att_download=y |title=Table A.1.1.8 - Gross domestic product at market prices (volume change rate; annual) |date=2013 |website= |publisher=Instituto Nacional de Estatística |access-date=3 July 2018 |quote=}}</ref> Ferreira Leite managed to keep deficit on 2.9% both in 2003 and in 2004, but through one-off and extraordinary measures.<ref name="2005 EC Report" /> Otherwise, the deficit would have hit the 5% mark.{{sfn|Commission of the European Communities|2005|p=8}} Meanwhile, the first half of the 2000s also saw the end of the downward trend in the [[Debt-to-GDP ratio|government debt to GDP ratio]] that marked the 1990s: the ratio rose from 53% in 2000 to 62% in 2004 (the ratio overtook the SGP's arbitrary limit of 60% in 2003).{{sfn|Commission of the European Communities|2005|p=13}}
Socialist [[José Sócrates]] became Prime Minister in [[2005 Portuguese legislative election|2005]]; like his Conservative predecessor, Sócrates tried to reduce the government's budget deficit through austerity and tax hikes, but refused to use extraordinary measures for the consolidation of public finances.{{sfn|Commission of the European Communities|2005|p=2}} By then, economy was clearly lagging behind European partners and the 2005 budget deficit was expected to be above 6% if no extraordinary measures were used.{{sfn|Commission of the European Communities|2005|p=11}} In the Stability and Growth Programme for 2005–2009, the government of Sócrates proposed to let the budget deficit to be higher than 6% in 2005, but to structurally reduce it to below 3% until 2008, a plan which was accepted by the European authorities.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.publico.pt/2005/06/22/mundo/noticia/programa-do-governo-para-reduzir-o-defice-levanta-duvidas-a-comissao-1226415 |title=Programa do Governo para reduzir o défice levanta dúvidas à Comissão |date=22 June 2005 |website= |publisher=Público |language=Portuguese |trans-title=Government’s plan to reduce deficit raises doubts to Commission |access-date=4 July 2018 |quote=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.publico.pt/2005/06/08/jornal/pec-portugues-foi-bem-recebido-pelo-eurogrupo-24528 |title=PEC português foi bem recebido pelo Eurogrupo |date=8 June 2005 |website= |publisher=Público |language=Portuguese |trans-title=Portugal’s Stability and Growth Programme was well received by Eurogroup |access-date=4 July 2018 |quote=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.publico.pt/2005/07/15/economia/noticia/portugal-tem-ate-2008-para-corrigir-defice-publico-1228310 |title=Portugal tem até 2008 para corrigir défice público |date=15 July 2005 |website= |publisher=Público |language=Portuguese |trans-title=Portugal has till 2008 to correct deficit |access-date=4 July 2018 |quote=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.publico.pt/2005/07/12/jornal/pec-portugues-e-hoje-aprovado-em-bruxelas-29844 |title=PEC português é hoje aprovado em Bruxelas |date=12 July 2005 |website= |publisher=Público |language=Portuguese |trans-title=Portuguese Stability and Growth Programme is approved today in Brussels |access-date=4 July 2018 |quote=}}</ref> {{lang|pt|A economia continuou a registrar positivos, porém pequenos, índices de crescimentos em 2005 (0.8%) e 2006 (1.4%)}}.<ref name="GDP growth" /> A notable milepost in the crisis happened in 2005, when the Portuguese [[unemployment rate]] overtook the European average for the first time since 1986.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://fronteirasxxi.pt/wp-content/uploads/2017/06/Infografia-A-economia-portuguesa-no-div%C3%A3.pdf |title=A economia portuguesa no divã |date=June 2017 |publisher=RTP |language=Portuguese |trans-title=The Portuguese economy at the divan |access-date=28 June 2018 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/70gO9rdyB?url=https://fronteirasxxi.pt/wp-content/uploads/2017/06/Infografia-A-economia-portuguesa-no-div%C3%A3.pdf |archive-date=5 July 2018 |url-status=live |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In 2007, the government achieved a 2.6% budget deficit (one year before target), below the 3.0% limit allowed by the [[Stability and Growth Pact]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.publico.pt/2008/03/26/economia/noticia/defice-ao-valor-mais-baixo-dos-ultimos-30-anos-1323730 |title=Défice ao valor mais baixo dos últimos 30 anos |date=26 March 2008 |website= |publisher=Público |language=Portuguese |trans-title=Lowest deficit in 30 years |access-date=4 July 2018 |quote=}}</ref> That year, the economy grew 2.4%, the highest rate in the decade (excluding 2000).<ref name="GDP growth" /> Nevertheless, also in 2007, the comparatively low growth rate made ''[[The Economist]]'' to describe Portugal as "a new [[sick man of Europe]]".<ref>[http://www.economist.com/world/europe/displaystory.cfm?story_id=9009032 "A new sick man of Europe"]. ''The Economist''</ref> From 2005 to 2007, public debt was stable at a ratio of approximately 68% of the GDP.<ref name="public debt to GDP ratio">{{cite web |url=https://www.pordata.pt/Portugal/Administra%C3%A7%C3%B5es+P%C3%BAblicas+d%C3%ADvida+bruta+em+percentagem+do+PIB-2786 |title=Administrações Públicas: dívida bruta em % do PIB |date= |website= |publisher=Pordata |language=Portuguese |trans-title=Government: public debt as share of GDP |access-date=4 July 2018 |quote=}}</ref>
The [[Great Recession]] started to hit Portugal in 2008; that year the Portuguese economy did not grow (0.0%) and fell almost 3% in 2009.<ref name="GDP growth" /> Meanwhile, the government reported a 2.6% budget deficit in 2008 which rose to almost 10% in 2009.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.publico.pt/2009/04/22/economia/noticia/eurostat-aceita-defice-de-2008-registado-por-portugal-1375901 |title=Eurostat aceita défice de 2008 registado por Portugal |last=Aníbal |first=Sérgio |date=22 April 2009 |website= |publisher=Público |language=Portuguese |trans-title=Eurostat accepts 2008 deficit reported by Portugal |access-date=5 July 2018 |quote=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.publico.pt/2010/04/22/economia/noticia/eurostat-validou-defice-de-94-por-cento-do-pib-em-2009-1433471 |title=Eurostat validou défice de 9,4 por cento do PIB em 2009 |date=22 April 2010 |website= |publisher=Público |language=Portuguese |trans-title=Eurostat validates 9.4% budget deficit for 2009 |access-date=5 July 2018 |quote=}}</ref> Austerity was somewhat waned in 2008–2010, as part of the [[2008 European Union stimulus plan|European economy recovery plan]] and the [[2008–09 Keynesian resurgence|resurgence of Keynesianism]] (which called for anti-cyclic policies), but was resumed in May 2010.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.jornaldenegocios.pt/economia/detalhe/soacutecrates_daacute_primeira_entrevista_apoacutes_aprovaccedilatildeo_do_pacote_de_austeridade |title=Sócrates dá primeira entrevista após aprovação do pacote de austeridade |date=17 May 2010 |website= |publisher=Jornal de Negócios |language=Portuguese |trans-title=Sócrates gives first interview following approval of the austerity package |access-date=28 June 2018 |quote=}}</ref> In 2010 there was economic growth (1.9%) but the financial status remained very difficult (8.6% budget deficit);<ref name="GDP growth" /><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.jn.pt/economia/interior/ine-corrige-o-defice-de-2010-para-86-do-pib-1819446.html |title=INE corrige o défice de 2010 para 8,6% do PIB |date=31 March 2011 |website= |publisher=Jornal de Notícias |language=Portuguese |trans-title=National Institute of Statistics corrects 2010 deficit to 8.6% of the GDP |access-date=5 July 2018 |quote=}}</ref> the country eventually became unable to repay or refinance its government debt and requested a bailout in April 2011; in 2011 the economy fell 1.3% and the government reported a 4.2% budget deficit.<ref name="GDP growth" /><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.jornaldenegocios.pt/economia/detalhe/portugal_fechou_2011_com_deacutefice_de_42_do_pib_act |title=Portugal fechou 2011 com défice de 4,2% do PIB |date=23 April 2012 |website= |publisher=Jornal de Negócios |language=Portuguese |trans-title=Portugal ended 2011 with a deficit of 4.2% or the GDP |access-date=5 July 2018 |quote=}}</ref> Meanwhile, government debt-to-GDP ratio sharply rose from 68% in 2007 to 111% in 2011.<ref name="public debt to GDP ratio" />
In the end, Portuguese economy grew less on a per capita basis in the 2000s and early 2010s than the American economy during the [[Great Depression]] or the Japanese economy during the [[Lost Decade (Japan)|Lost Decade]].<ref name="The Atlantic 2013" />.<ref name="The Atlantic 2013" /> Despite government policies openly aimed to consolidate the Portuguese public finances,{{refn|group=note|name=note1|An "everyday" example of the tax hikes during the 2000s crisis is the [[Value added tax|VAT]]'s standard rate, which rose from 17% in 2002 to 23% in 2011.}} Portugal was almost always under excessive deficit procedure{{refn|group=note|name=note2|In the 2000s and early 2010s, Portugal was under excessive deficit procedure (EDP) in 2002–2004, 2005–2008 and from 2009 on (this last EDP was closed in 2017).<ref>{{cite web |url=https://ec.europa.eu/info/business-economy-euro/economic-and-fiscal-policy-coordination/eu-economic-governance-monitoring-prevention-correction/stability-and-growth-pact/corrective-arm-excessive-deficit-procedure/closed-excessive-deficit-procedures/portugal_en |title=Closed Excessive Deficit Procedures — Portugal |author=<!--Not stated--> |date= 2016-10-03|website= |publisher=European Commission |access-date=5 July 2018 |quote=}}</ref>}} and government debt-to-GDP ratio rose from 50% in 2000 to 68% in 2007 and 126% in 2012.<ref name="public debt to GDP ratio" /> The causes of the stagnation are complex, as many potential causes also affect other Southern European countries and did not prevent them from growing in the 2000s, nor did prevent Portugal from growing before the early 2000s.<ref name="The Atlantic 2013" /><ref name="Portugal, um país de crise em crise" /> Economist [[:pt:João Martins Ferreira do Amaral|Ferreira do Amaral]] points to the accession to [[Euro]] in 1999–2002, which was too strong as a currency for Portugal's economy and industry and took away from the country the ability to direct its own monetary (rise or reduce interest rates) and cambial policy (currency devaluation).<ref name="Portugal, um país de crise em crise">{{cite web |url=https://fronteirasxxi.pt/portugal-um-pais-de-crise-em-crise/ |title=Portugal, um país de crise em crise |last=Romano |first=Pedro |date=2017 |publisher=RTP |language=Portuguese |trans-title=Portugal: a country from crisis to crisis |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/70emZmgEx?url=https://fronteirasxxi.pt/portugal-um-pais-de-crise-em-crise/ |archive-date=4 July 2018 |access-date=4 July 2018 |url-status=live |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jun/04/portuguese-bestseller-leave-euro-eurosceptic |title=Portuguese bestselling book recommends leaving the euro |date=4 June 2013 |newspaper=The Guardian |access-date=3 July 2018 |quote=|last1=Vergès |first1=Marie de }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.project-syndicate.org/commentary/jo-o-ferreira-do-amaral-et-al-propose-a-strategy-for-saving-the-european-union-from-the-euro |title=Deconstructing the Euro |date=25 March 2014 |website= |publisher=Project Syndicate |access-date=3 July 2018 |quote=}}</ref> [[Vítor Bento]] also thinks that the belonging to a currency union created numerous challenges to which the Portuguese economy was not able to adapt.<ref name="Portugal, um país de crise em crise" /> Bento also points out that Euro was the root cause for many the internal macroeconomic disequilibria inside Eurozone — such as excessive external deficits in periphery countries (such as Portugal) and excessive external surplus in core countries — and that such disequilibria were the main cause of the 2010s [[European debt crisis]] (and were, to a great extent, more to important to explain the crisis than states' public finances).<ref>{{cite web |url=https://observador.pt/especiais/eurocrise-uma-outra-perspectiva/ |title=Eurocrise: uma outra perspectiva |last=Bento |first=Vítor |date=8 February 2015 |website= |publisher=Observador |language=Portuguese |trans-title=Eurocrisis: another perspective |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20180705105545/https://observador.pt/especiais/eurocrise-uma-outra-perspectiva/ |archive-date=5 July 2018|access-date=5 July 2018 |quote=}}</ref> A set of economists (including former Prime Minister and eventual President [[Cavaco Silva]]) points to the excessive size of the Portuguese government, whose total expenditures overtook 45% of the GDP in 2005.<ref name="Portugal, um país de crise em crise" /> Such hypothesis was eventually the basis for the austerity requested as conditionality for the [[Economic Adjustment Programme for Portugal|2011–2014 European Union/IMF bailout]].<ref name="Portugal, um país de crise em crise" /> For [[Ricardo Reis]], the accession to Euro was a root cause for the 2000s crisis, but for different reasons than the ones put forward by Ferreira do Amaral: the low interest rates allowed an influx of foreign capital, which the country's weak financial system misallocated to the low-productive non-tradable sector, reducing the economy's overall productivity.<ref name="Reis 2013">{{cite journal |last1=Reis |first1=Ricardo |date=August 2013 |title=The Portuguese Slump and Crash and the Euro Crisis |journal=Brookings Papers on Economic Activity, Economic Studies Program |volume=46 |issue=1 |pages=143–210 |doi=10.3386/w19288 |doi-access=free }}</ref><ref name="Portugal, um país de crise em crise" /> Meanwhile, the Social Security system was demanding increasing public spending, and the constant tax hikes in the 2000s limited the potential for growth of the Portuguese economy.<ref name="Reis 2013" /><ref name="Portugal, um país de crise em crise" /> It is noteworthy that from 2000 to 2007, taxes as share of GDP increased 1.7% in Portugal but declined 0.9% in Eurozone.<ref name="Reis 2013" /> Another factor at the root of the stagnation may be that Portuguese economy faced increasing competition by Eastern European countries and China, which were economies also specialized in low wages and low-value-added goods.<ref name="Reis 2013" /> Other more structural problems identified were excessive corruption and regulation, which makes difficult for business to get bigger and achieve economies-of-scale,<ref name="The Atlantic 2013" /> as also the low educational attainment of Portuguese adults, low total factor productivity, rigid labour market laws and an inefficient and slow judicial system.<ref name="Reis 2013" />
===Anxiety on financial markets=== After the [[financial crisis of 2007–2008]], it was known in 2008–2009 that two Portuguese banks ([[Banco Português de Negócios]] (BPN) and [[Banco Privado Português]] (BPP)) had been accumulating losses for years due to bad investments, embezzlement and accounting fraud. The case of BPN was particularly serious because of its size, market share, and the political implications - Portugal's then current President, Cavaco Silva, and some of his political allies, maintained personal and business relationships with the bank and its CEO, who was eventually charged and arrested for fraud and other crimes.<ref>{{Cite web | url=https://expresso.sapo.pt/bpn-oliveira-costa-vendeu-a-cavaco-e-filha-250-mil-acoes-da-sln=f643506 | title=Expresso | BPN: Oliveira Costa vendeu a Cavaco e filha 250 mil ações da SLN}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dn.pt/inicio/portugal/interior.aspx?content_id=1756013 |title=Diário de Notícias |accessdate=2013-05-12 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140816131039/http://www.dn.pt/inicio/portugal/interior.aspx?content_id=1756013 |archivedate=16 August 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web | url=http://www.jn.pt/PaginaInicial/Seguranca/Interior.aspx?content_id=2623133 | title=Dias Loureiro entre os dirigentes do PSD no processo-crime do BPN}}</ref> In the grounds of avoiding a potentially serious financial crisis in the Portuguese economy, the Portuguese government decided to give them a bailout, eventually at a future loss to taxpayers.
In the opening weeks of 2010, renewed anxiety about the excessive levels of debt in some EU countries and, more generally, about the health of the Euro spread from Ireland and Greece to Portugal, Spain, and Italy. In 2010, [[PIIGS]] and PIGS acronyms were widely used by international bond analysts, academics, and the international economic press when referring to these under performing economies.
Some senior German policy makers went as far as to say that emergency bailouts to Greece and future EU aid recipients should bring with it harsh penalties.<ref>{{in lang|en}} {{Citation|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-02-15/merkel-economy-adviser-says-greece-bailout-should-bring-penalty.html |accessdate=15 February 2010 |title=Merkel Economy Adviser Says Greece Bailout Should Bring Penalty |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100219060101/http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-02-15/merkel-economy-adviser-says-greece-bailout-should-bring-penalty.html |archivedate=19 February 2010 |df=dmy }}</ref>
Robert Fishman, in the New York Times article "Portugal's Unnecessary Bailout", points out that Portugal fell victim to successive waves of speculation by pressure from bond traders, rating agencies and speculators.<ref name="fishman-portugal">[https://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/13/opinion/13fishman.html Portugal’s Unnecessary Bailout] – The New York Times</ref> In the first quarter of 2010, before pressure from the markets, Portugal had one of the best rates of economic recovery in the EU. From the perspective of Portugal's industrial orders, exports, entrepreneurial innovation and high-school achievement, the country matched or even surpassed its neighbors in Western Europe.<ref name="fishman-portugal" /> However, the Portuguese economy had been creating its own problems over a lengthy period of time, which came to a head with the financial crisis. Persistent and lasting recruitment policies boosted the number of redundant public servants. Risky credit, public debt creation, and European structural and cohesion funds were mismanaged across almost four decades.{{Citation needed|date=January 2016}}
In the summer of 2010, [[Moody's]] Investors Service cut Portugal's [[sovereign bond]] rating down two notches from an Aa2 to an A1<ref>[[Bond credit rating]]s</ref> Due to spending on economic stimuli, Portugal's [[debt]] had increased sharply compared to the gross domestic product. Moody noted that the rising debt would weigh heavily on the government's short-term finances.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/10610673.stm BBC News -Moody's downgrades Portugal debt]</ref>
=== Austerity measures amid increased pressure on government bonds === In September 2010, the Portuguese Government announced a fresh austerity package following other [[Eurozone]] partners, through a series of tax hikes and salary cuts for [[public servant]]s. In 2009, the deficit had been 9.4 percent, one of the highest in the Eurozone and well above the [[European Union]]'s [[Stability and Growth Pact]] three percent limit. In November [[risk premium]]s on Portuguese [[bond (finance)|bond]]s hit euro lifetime highs as investors and creditors worried that the country would fail to rein in its budget deficit and debt. The yield on the country's 10-year government bonds reached 7 percent – a level the Portuguese Finance Minister [[Fernando Teixeira dos Santos]] had previously said would require the country to seek financial help from international institutions. Also in 2010, the country reached a record high unemployment rate of nearly 11%, a figure not seen for over two decades, while the number of [[public servant]]s remained very high.
On 23 March 2011, José Sócrates resigned following passage of a [[no confidence]] motion sponsored by all five opposition parties in parliament over spending cuts and tax increases.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.france24.com/en/20110323-portuguese-parliament-votes-against-austerity-plan-jose-socrates-eurozone |title=Portuguese parliament votes against austerity plan |date=23 March 2011 |accessdate=23 March 2011 |publisher=[[France 24]]}}</ref>
In the first half of 2011, Portugal requested a €78 billion IMF-EU bailout package in a bid to stabilise its public finances.[128] After the bailout was announced, the Portuguese government headed by Pedro Passos Coelho managed to implement measures to improve the State's financial situation and the country started to be seen as moving on the right track.{{Citation needed|date=January 2016}} This also led to a strong increase of the unemployment rate to over 15 per cent in the second quarter 2012 and it is expected to rise even further in the near future.{{citation needed|date=April 2020}}
==Economic Adjustment Programme for Portugal== {{main|Economic Adjustment Programme for Portugal}}
==Re-access to financial markets== A positive turning point in Portugal's strive to regain access to financial markets, was achieved on 3 October 2012, when the state managed to convert €3.76 billion of bonds with maturity in September 2013 (carrying a 3.10% yield) to new bonds with maturity in October 2015 (carrying a 5.12% yield). Before the bond exchange, the state had a total of €9.6 billion outstanding notes due in 2013, which according to the bailout plan should be renewed by the sale of new bonds on the market. As Portugal was already able to renew one-third of the outstanding bonds at a reasonable yield level, the market now expect the upcoming renewals in 2013 also to be conducted at reasonable yield levels. The bailout funding programme will run until June 2014, but at the same time require Portugal to regain a complete bond market access on September 2013. The recent sale of bonds with a 3-year maturity, was the first bond sale of the Portuguese state since requesting the bailout in April 2011, and the first step slowly to open up its governmental bond market again. Recently the ECB announced they will be ready also, to begin additional support to Portugal, with some yield-lowering bond purchases ([[Outright Monetary Transactions|OMTs]]), when the country regained complete market access.<ref name="October 2012 status">{{cite web|url=http://www.ekathimerini.com/4dcgi/_w_articles_wsite2_1_03/10/2012_464362 |title=Portugal seeks market access with $5 bln bond exchange |publisher=Kathimerini (English Edition) |date=3 October 2012 |accessdate=17 October 2012 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121005235156/http://www.ekathimerini.com/4dcgi/_w_articles_wsite2_1_03/10/2012_464362 |archivedate=5 October 2012 }}</ref> All together this bodes well for a further decline of the governmental interest rates in Portugal, which on 30 January 2012 had a peak for the 10-year rate at 17.3% (after the rating agencies had cut the governments credit rating to "non-investment grade" -also referred to as "junk"),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://markets.ft.com/RESEARCH/markets/DataArchiveFetchReport?Category=BR&Type=SPR&Date=01/30/2012|title=Data archive for bonds and rates (Ten-year government bond spreads on 30 January 2012)|format=PDF|publisher=Financial Times|date=30 January 2012|accessdate=24 November 2012}}</ref> and as of 24 November 2012 has been more than halved to only 7.9%.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.forexpros.com/rates-bonds/portugal-10-year-bond-yield-historical-data|title=Portugal 10-Year Futures Historical Data|publisher=ForexPros.com|date=24 November 2012|accessdate=24 November 2012}}</ref>
==Rejection of Austerity Conditions and Political Crisis== In the [[2015 Portuguese legislative election|parliamentary elections of October 2015]], the ruling right wing party failed to achieve an operating majority despite having won the elections by a solid margin. An anti-austerity post-electoral left wing coalition was formed achieving 51% of the vote and 53% of elected MPs, however, the President of Portugal at first refused to allow the left wing coalition to govern, inviting the minority right wing coalition to form a government. This was formed in November 2015 and lasted 11 days when it lost motion of confidence. The President eventually invited and asked the Socialist Party to form a government supported by 123 of 230 MPs in parliament from all parties except the former right wing coalition which broke into two parties. The new government (of the Socialist Party and independents) took office in November 2015 with a parliamentary majority thanks to the support of the Left Bloc, the Green Party and the Communist Party and the abstention of the Animal Welfare Party (PAN). In 2017, the IMF saw a 2.5 percent growth rate and an unemployment rate below 10 percent, but the European Commission expected Portugal's Government debt to reach 128.5 percent of GDP.<ref>https://www.cnbc.com/2017/08/02/how-portugal-came-back-from-the-brink.html</ref>
==Key economic data in 2016== * Budget deficit in 2016 was 2.1% of GDP, 0.4% the arbitrary limit set for it by the EC, the lowest since 1974, and less than half of the previous government's last year in power 2015. It is also 0.9% below the limits agreed at Maastricht. * In 2016, Portuguese GDP was $259 billion, up by about 3% from 2015, and 21% from its record low in 2012. * In 2016, Portugal registered a 14-year sequence of continuous increases in [[debt-to-GDP ratio]]s, i.e., since the adoption of the Euro as currency. * In 2016, combined sovereign and personal debt in Portugal was the 5th largest in the Eurozone, reaching a combined 390% of GDP * In April 2017, the unemployment rate was 9.5%, over 8% below the all-time high reached in 2013 though still slightly above the 43 year average since the country became a democracy.
